results.title: Thoroughbreds for the world
results.brief_description:
Episode of series “This modern age”
Explains that thoroughbred horses are descended from family lines originally developed in England, during the 18th century. A large breeding industry, maintained to meet overseas demand for British thoroughbreds is kept at a high standard by careful selective breeding. There are glimpses of British horses, or their immediate descendants, at studs and in races in many parts of the world.

results.title: Sudan dispute
results.creator_credit: J. Arthur Rank Organisation and This Modern Age
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “This Modern Age”
Discusses the dispute between Egypt and England over the future of the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan. As a background, it shows the nature of the peoples who inhabit the area and claims that improvements in health services, education and agriculture are the result of British administration.

results.title: Struggle for oil
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Modern Age”
Discusses the importance of oil in the world of today. Traces the growth of the oil industry from the beginning of the century, during the first and second world wars and in the post-war era. The Middle East as a source of oil is considered and the need for political stability in these areas emphasised. This stability can only be guaranteed if the rulers of these countries use profits from oil to improve the conditions of the people.

results.title: Shadow of the Ruhr
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Modern Age”.
For fifty years the Ruhr Valley has been the key to Germany’s economy in war and peace; but because it is essentially a heavy-industry area, the Ruhr is also the arsenal and aggressive potential of Germany. At the end of World War 2, the Ruhr Valley was in ruins - factories, foundries, mines, warehouses, and homes reduced to rubble and ashes, the people short of food, without shelter, and with little prospect of employment. The policy of the Allies immediately after WW2 was to prevent the Ruhr from ever producing arms again; but as friction between the great nations has increased in the post-war world, the western powers have once again begun to develop the Ruhr’s armaments industries.

results.title: Scotland Yard
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Modern Age”.
Aspects of the work of Scotland Yard detectives are illustrated in an accident following a warehouse robbery and how the various Yard departments and other police departments work in cooperation. Traces the case through from the stealing of a car carrying a load of tea to the conviction of the criminals involved in it. Briefly shows the various methods of identification, namely, by fingerprint, by photograph, and on parade in front of a witness.

results.title: Report on Hong Kong
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Modern Age”.
A study of the strategic, political, economic and social situation of Hong Kong. Stresses its relationship to China; its ties, through trade, with the rest of the world; its vital importance in Far Eastern affairs; its administrative and social difficulties owing to over-population. Scenes of the port, vegetable growing and marketing, factories, shipyards, the airfield, water reservoirs, the fishing industry. Illustrations of its political, housing, medical, educational and military problems.

results.title: The Rape of the earth
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Modern Age”.
This film puts squarely before its audience the seriousness of the question of world-wide misuse of the soil resources of the earth. Primitive peoples have not caused more devastation than civilised peoples; in fact, they have caused less, for civilised humans organises agricultural and pastoral activities on a greater scale.

results.title: Lancashire's time for adventure
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Modern Age”.
For more than 200 years cotton, grown on the other side of the world, has been coming to Britain to be spun and woven. A moist climate, money for the development of mills, and inventors whose machines taught mass-production to the world - Lancashire had all these. But today one-third of Lancashire’s spindles and looms are idle. The memory of past booms and slumps has resulted in a grave shortage of operators. Schemes to improve working conditions and wages have been put into operation.

results.title: Jamaica problem
results.brief_description:
Episode number 14 of Series “This Modern Age”.
A discussion on problems which confront Jamaica in the modern world. The economy of the island is dependent on sugar, bananas and rum - if the crops fail, heavy unemployment is the result. Population, which has doubled in 25 years, is also a problem. The film suggests irrigation, research on diseases, education and sound political leadership, afforestation and diversification of industries as solutions to the economic and social problems of the troubled island.

results.title: Homes for all
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “This Modern Age”.
This film stresses the plight of Britain’s homeless in 1946, tracing its causes, and pointing the way to a possible solution to the problem. The growth of industries, with the consequent expansion of cities, and the age of jerry-building are dealt with in some detail.
